moves.1. e4:
Hi everyone!

Gerhard (Chicoboy) asked me to annotate this game.  It was a game from Charleshiggie's Group J Training Tournament.  It is white who cops Old Matey - so, how does this happen?  Well, there is a plethora of unusual opening moves from white including a lotta pawn moves, so black does get a lead in development in the opening.  Well, we shall see how the game pans out .......
moves.1... Nc6 2. d3 e5 3. f4: 3. f4 - so Chris decided to answer Gerhard's Nimzowich Defense with a delayed King's Gambit.
moves.3... f6: 3. ..... f6 - which transposes into Damiano's Defense on the next turn!
moves.4. Nf3 Bc5 5. c3 d6 6. b4 Bb6 7. a4: 7. a4 - thee has been a series of pawn pushing.  I see the sense in this pawn roll though.  Chris is trying to trap Gerhard's dsb.
moves.7... a5: 7. ..... a5 - and Gerhard creates a bolt-hole.
moves.11... g5 12. dxe5 Bxf3 13. Bxf3 Qxd1+ 14: 14. Bxd1 - a plethora of exchanges results in Gerhard being a pawn down.  Can Chris make use of the extra pawn though?  Only time will tell.
moves.14... h6 15. Bh5+ Kf8 16. exf6 Nxf6: 16. ..... Nxf6 - Gerhard's king knight develops at last.  Now Gerhard must sort out where he is gonna put his king.
moves.17. Bf3 g4 18. Be2: 18. Be2 - Chris' lsb has been pushed back.  Now what?
moves.18... h5 19. e5 Ne4: 19. .... Ne4 - Gerhard's knight has been driven to a better square.  This move puts a little pressure on the isolani on c3.
moves.22. Na3 Ne4 23. c4 Rd8: 23. ..... Rd8 - although the rooks are still unconnected, Gerhard does manage to centralise the queen rook.
moves.24. h3 g3: 24. .... g3 - although Chris is a piece to the bad, you wouldn't think he was gonna cop Old Matey in just two moves, would you?
moves.25. Rf4 Bf2+: 25. ..... Bf2+ - white must now give up his rook to avoid losing his king!
moves.26. Kf1 Nd2#: 26. ..... Nd2 MATE!! Sadly white opts for sudden death.  Chris is a piece for a pawn light in the final position and with the endgame approaching this would have no doubt been decisive in Gerhard's favour anyway.  As snap mates go, this one is a beauty!  Well played Gerhard!
